title: Delta and the Bannermen
dialogue_triumphs: The Doctor: 'Love has never been known for its rationality.'
The Doctor: 'Many a slap 'twixt a cup and a lap.'
Burton to the Doctor: 'You are not the Happy Hearts Holiday Club from Bolton, but instead are spacemen in fear of an attack from some other spacemen?'
goofs: The rubber bodies on the ground during the initial battle.
McCoy wears his glasses in the long shots when he's driving the bike.
The Doctor says the explosion of the sonic cone will destroy everyone, so why doesn't it?
Why isn't Billy poisoned by the alien food? (Why does it, instead, turn him into a Chimeron?)

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor's question-mark umbrella
continuity_notes.description: The Seventh Doctor's iconic umbrella with a question mark handle makes its first appearance in this story.
continuity_notes.current_status: Introduced as part of the Seventh Doctor's outfit

continuity_notes.name: Navarinos
continuity_notes.description: Squat, wrinkly purple creatures who can shapechange and time travel. They have a high metabolic rate and seem to have similarities with Time Lords.
continuity_notes.current_status: Peaceful time-traveling species, possibly permitted by Time Lords

continuity_notes.name: Chimerons
continuity_notes.description: An alien species with green males and infants, and humanoid females. They have been nearly wiped out by the Bannermen.
continuity_notes.current_status: Near extinction due to conflict with Bannermen

continuity_notes.name: Bannermen
continuity_notes.description: A group responsible for the genocide of the Chimerons, possibly subject to punishment by a higher authority (possibly the Time Lords).
continuity_notes.current_status: Antagonists in the story, pursuing the remaining Chimerons

continuity_notes.name: Goronwy
continuity_notes.description: A mysterious old man who seems familiar with the Doctor and alien concepts, possibly a Time Lord in disguise.
continuity_notes.current_status: Assisting the Doctor, hinted to have a secret identity

roots: 50s nostalgia films (American Graffiti, Peggy Sue Got Married, Back to the Future)

locations.name: Shangri-La holiday camp
locations.description: A holiday camp near Llandrudnod Wells, Wales, serving as the main setting for the story.

locations.name: Toll point in space
locations.description: A future location in space where time travelers pay a toll, possibly near Navaro and on one of the Navarinos' main routes.
locations.current_status: Active toll collection point for time travelers

untold_adventures: Mel's previous encounter with the Bannermen (implied)
additional_notes: Murray reads The Eagle. Sylvester McCoy has trouble with 'high impulse beam' in episode two. Ray's bow makes her look like a Mouseketeer. Mel's pyjamas are rather woeful.
bottom_line: Confident, slick, and hugely enjoyable from beginning to end, 'Delta and the Bannermen' isn't grim, gritty or cynical, and is thus tremendously adult. It roars with new style. This is the first real hint of McCoy's Doctor, dancing awkwardly with Ray, hugging a Stratocaster, confronting Gavrok and threatening the Bannermen. Langford is actually great in this, a very human story of sex, drugs and rock'n'roll. Even Ken Dodd's OK. But who told Don Henderson to play it so straight?
